thread.section_title: Baseball and MLB News | Sports | Toronto Star
thread.title: Ryan Goins shines, Blue Jays survive Royals rally to win Game 3
thread.title_full: Ryan Goins shines, Blue Jays survive Royals rally to win Game 3 | Toronto Star

author: Mark Zwolinski
title: Ryan Goins shines, Blue Jays survive Royals rally to win Game 3
text:
Photos View photos zoom The power came back on at the Rogers Centre Monday night.
Toronto’s home run-fuelled offence came to life after falling dormant for two games, stunning Kansas City and its ace, Johnny Cueto, in a 11-8 win before 49,751 fans in Game 3 of the American League Championship Series.
But the real star in the midst of Toronto’s big win, which brought them back to 2-1 in the best-of-seven affair, was second baseman Ryan Goins.
Dragging the residual guilt of a game-changing misplay in Game 2, Goins exploded with a two-run single in the third inning and a solo homer in the fifth for one very memorable night.
Call it the “Goins Redemption,” and, coupled with homers from Troy Tulowitzki and Josh Donaldson, the Jays collected three overall after going homerless in their first two games.
That attack targeted – and destroyed – Cueto, the swaggering Royals star, who was dominant in his previous start in the Royals ALDS clinching win over Houston.
Not so much, though, Monday, as the Jays punched him out six batters into the third inning. Cueto, though, was true to form, gesturing and smirking to the crowd as he strode off the field.
Jays starter Marcus Stroman scattered 11 hits and four runs over a 6.1-inning effort that was effective if not dominant; most importantly, the young gun once again delivered in a high-pressure situation, the fourth such game he’s done so since his storied comeback in September from a devastating knee injury in spring training.
Now trailing the series 2-1 , the Jays turn to knuckle baller R.A. Dickey Tuesday night in Game 4, while the Royals counter with 6-foot-10 right-hander Chris Young (whose wife Elizabeth, is the grand daughter of hockey legend Lester Patrick, the namesake of the NHL’s Patrick Division and Lester Patrick Trophy).
Toronto fell behind 1-0 within the first three pitches of the game from Stroman, who gave up a lead-off triple to Alcides Escobar and an RBI ground out to second from Ben Zobrist.
Zobrist, whom the Jays have sought in deadline trades the past three seasons, put the ball in play to the right side of the infield to score the run – a typical piece of hitting that has characterized the Royals since their World Series drive last season.
Toronto rebounded with a three-run inning in the second, triggered by Goins two-run double in a great at-bat against Cueto. Goins worked the count to full at 3-2, then took a weak slider to the left field to bring in the runs. Donaldson followed with a single to score Goins with that third run.
Cueto, with 50 pitches on board after two innings, and bombarded with jeers from a raucous Rogers Centre crowd ever for a Jays game, collapsed in the third; he delivered a flat fastball over the heart of the plate to Tulowitzki for a three-run homer that proved the crushing blow for the Royals.
Donaldson followed up five batters later with a two-run shot off reliever Kris Medlen, the second homer of the inning, but the runs were charged to Cueto in what was a nightmarish frame.
By the time it was over, Toronto had boarded six runs, with the first six batters of the inning reaching base safely. Overall, Cueto lasted just two innings plus six batters – he was tagged for six hits and eight runs overall on 69 pitches.
Toronto went 6-for-10, with a homer, a hit batter, a stolen base, and four walks, against Cueto after he retired the first two batters of the game in order.
Tulowitzki bagged his eighth RBI of the post-season, tying him for sixth all-time in club history for the most RBI in a post-season. He also became the first Jay ever with multiple three-run homers (his second) in the post-season. He was also ejected for arguing balls and strikes in the eight inning.
Donaldson joined Joe Carter and Candy Maldonado (92), and Paul Molitor (93), as the only Jays with three post-season homers (no one has ever hit four).
The six-run third also tied a club record for the most runs scored in a single inning in post-season history.
